title: Blaenau Ffestiniog Walks

images.title: Martin Bodman / Blaenau Ffestiniog: Bethania
images.caption: Blaenau Ffestiniog: Bethania. A slate mill, then a woollen mill, Pant-yr-ynn, now a house conversion, survives above the street on the right-hand side. It was powered by the stream that provides the waterfall and the overshot waterwheel survives

images.title: Eric Jones / Melin Pant-yr-Ynn Slate Mill, Bethania
images.caption: Melin Pant-yr-Ynn Slate Mill, Bethania. Pant-yr-Ynn means "hollow of the ash (trees)". This was the earliest slate mill to be established in the Blaenau area. Later, it was converted into a woollen mill and only closed in 1964. Sited below the waterfall, its still operative 24' diameter wheel is powered by the fast flowing waters of Afon Du-bach ("little black stream"). The listed Grade II building is now an artist's studio, but is open by arrangement to visitors.

images.title: Eric Jones / Llyn y Manod
images.caption: Llyn y Manod is a deep, dark and, often, sunless lake. Nevertheless, it has traditionally been regarded as a good trout fishing lake. It has an area of 8.3ha.

images.title: Eric Jones / A party of walkers on the eastern shore of Llyn y Manod
images.caption: A party of walkers on the eastern shore of Llyn y Manod. These walkers are following an old quarryman's track through Bwlch y Manod.

images.title: Vivien and Geoff Crowder / Llyn Bowydd
images.caption: Llyn Bowydd. Llyn Bowydd and Llyn Newydd from the upper northern slopes of Manod Mawr. The peak at middle right is Moel Penamnen with the Snowdon massif and the Glyder range beyond in the distance.

images.title: Eric Jones / View south across Llyn Newydd
images.caption: View south across Llyn Newydd. This 12 acre reservoir was formed in the 1860s, when mountain streams were dammed, to provide water for the Maen Offeren Slate Quarry. The lake is bordered by a blanket bog.

images.title: Andrew Hill / Railway bridge, houses and hillside, Blaenau Ffestiniog
images.caption: Railway bridge, houses and hillside, Blaenau Ffestiniog. View to the bridge linking Newborough Street and Maenofferen Street from the Glynllifon Street bridge, with the obligatory slate mountain backdrop.

images.title: Anthony Brunning / Slate Quarry Train, Blaenau Ffestiniog, Gwynedd
images.caption: Slate Quarry Train. Slate Quarry Train now in the car park in the centre of Blaenau Ffestiniog.

description: This old slate mining town is located in Gwynedd in the Snowdonia National Park. It is a popular visitor destination with attractions including the heritage Ffestiniog Railway and the fascinating Llechwedd Slate Caverns. For walkers there are several good trails to try in the surrounding hills and mountains. This circular walk explores the area to the east of the town. On the trail you'll visit lovely waterfalls and several pretty lakes with fine views over Snowdonia to enjoy from the high points. The walk starts from Bethania, just to the south east of the train station and town centre. From here you can follow footpaths north east to the waterfall. The path continues east to visit Llyn Y Manod, the first of several attractive lakes on the route. You then turn north to pass a series of lakes including Llyn Glas, Llyn Du Bach, Llyn y Drum-boeth, Llyn Bowydd and Llyn Newydd. These last two lakes are somewhat larger than the others and are set in a beautiful, elevated position above the town. They sit on the slopes of Manod Mawr, where you can enjoy wonderful views to Moel Penamnen, the Snowdon massif and the Glyder range of mountains. The path then branches round to the west, towards Moel Bowydd, skirting the edge of the Maen-offeren Quarries. You then descend south to reenter the town.
